definition[0]: not being used or not needed at the present time
example[0]: Have you got any spare boxes?
example[1]: You could sleep in the spare bedroom.
example[2]: Do you have any spare cash?
example[3]: I’ll go and see if there are any spare seats.
example[4]: A decline in beer sales had left the industry with spare capacity  (=the ability to produce more than can be sold).
definition[1]: a spare style of writing, painting etc is plain or basic and uses nothing unnecessary
definition[2]: someone who is spare is tall and thin
definition[3]: to make something such as time, money, or workers available for someone, especially when this is difficult for you to do
example[5]: Sorry, I can’t spare the time.
example[6]: I’d like you to come over when you can spare a couple of hours.
example[8]: It’s very kind of you to spare me so much of your time.
example[9]: Could you possibly spare me a few moments in private  (=used to ask someone if they have time to quickly talk to you)?
note[0]: spare somebody ten minutes/an hour etc
example[10]: We’re too busy to spare anyone to help you right now.
definition[4]: to not damage or harm someone or something, even though other people or things are being damaged, killed, or destroyed
example[11]: I could not understand why I had been spared and they had not.
example[12]: the soldier who had spared his life
example[13]: Today we will hear whether the school is to be spared from closure.
definition[5]: an additional thing, for example a key, that you keep so that it is available
example[14]: If you forget the key, Mrs Jones over the road has a spare.
example[15]: The batteries are dead. Have you got any spares?
